questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe chest discomfort. The chest discomfort usually occurs after heavy meals or eating in the late evening and lasts several hours. He has nausea sometimes but no vomiting. He has also had an occasional nighttime cough during this period. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 41 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include metformin, naproxen, enalapril, and sitagliptin. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows no abnormalities. An upper endoscopy shows that the Z-line is located 4 cm above the diaphragmatic hiatus and reveals the presence of a 1.5-cm esophageal ulcer with an erythematous base and without bleeding. Esophageal biopsy specimens show no signs of dysplasia. The physician recommends weight loss as well as smoking and alcohol cessation. Treatment with omeprazole once daily is begun. Two months later, the patient's symptoms are unchanged. Omeprazole is stopped and pantoprazole therapy twice daily is begun. After two months, the patient still has severe chest discomfort. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Tetracycline, metronidazole, bismuth, and omeprazole therapy for 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optimized bismuth quadruple therapy is used to treat H. pylori infection, most commonly when patients present with complications of infection such as gastric or duodenal ulceration. In H. pylori infection, ulceration is caused not by gastric acid reflux but by altered secretion and tissue injury. Duodenal ulcers may manifest with epigastric pain occurring several hours after a meal, which is not consistent with this patient's immediate postprandial pain. While a gastric ulcer could be consistent with this patient's nausea and postprandial epigastric pain, gastric (and duodenal) ulcers were not found on upper endoscopy. Therefore, while H. pylori cannot be definitively excluded, it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms, and treatment for H. pylori would not be indicated at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Herniotomy is used to resect the gastric fundus or other abdominal structures not continuous with the esophagus that protrude into the mediastinum in type II, III, and IV hiatal hernias. Although this patient does have a hiatal hernia, the clinical history and endoscopy findings are consistent with a type I hiatal hernia. In type II “paraesophageal” and type IV “complex” hiatal hernias, the Z-line would not be displaced, as abdominal structures herniate separately next to the esophagus. In type III or “mixed” hiatal hernias, patients typically present with retching and early satiety (due to herniation of the gastric fundus next to the esophagus), which this patient does not report.

C) CORRECT:

Laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication with hiatoplasty is the definitive treatment for type I or “sliding” hiatal hernias with severe symptoms such as bleeding, ulcerations, and strictures. This patient has a type I hiatal hernia and was found to have an esophageal ulcer, indicating severe GERD, likely secondary to his hiatal hernia. Lifestyle modification (e.g., weight loss, exercise) and medical management (PPIs, H2-receptor antagonists) are first-line treatments for GERD. However, this patient has refractory symptoms despite trialling two PPIs and increasing the dosage. Therefore, given his endoscopic findings and the severity of his condition, surgical intervention should be considered.

Incidentally discovered sliding hiatal hernias in asymptomatic patients can be managed conservatively with reassurance and observation.
Image Description:

Type I (sliding): The gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) and the gastric cardia slide up into the mediastinum while the gastric fundus remains below the diaphragm.
Type II (paraesophageal): Part of the gastric fundus herniates into the thorax while the GEJ remains in its anatomical position below the diaphragm.
Type III (mixed): The GEJ and a portion of the gastric fundus prolapse through the hiatus.
Type IV (complex): herniation of any abdominal structure in addition to the stomach (e.g., colon, spleen)

D) INCORRECT:

Antacids such as calcium carbonate can be used for on-demand symptom relief in patients with mild symptoms of GERD. Patients with suspected GERD are typically started on a trial of PPI therapy for 2 months. If symptoms do not improve, the dosage can be increased or a different agent can be given. Afterwards, if symptoms are still refractory, further evaluation with endoscopy should be conducted. However, in the case above, the patient already underwent an endoscopy that showed a sliding hiatal hernia with an esophageal ulcer. Antacid therapy would not bring sufficient relief; definitive management is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Bariatric surgery (e.g., sleeve gastrectomy) may be indicated in obese patients with and without related complications, including GERD, and can lead to weight loss and subsequently decreased intraabdominal pressure and improvement of GERD symptoms. However, bariatric surgery is usually not indicated for overweight patients; lifestyle interventions and weight loss should be considered first. Moreover, this patient's sliding hiatal hernia is likely directly contributing to this patient's severe GERD and sleeve gastrectomy will not treat this condition.
questions.hint: This overweight patient has severe chest discomfort following large meals and eating late (likely related to lying down) and an occasional nighttime cough, suggesting gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The endoscopy shows a type I hiatal hernia and an esophageal ulcer, which indicates severe GERD.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 weeks after she was treated endoscopically for gastric angiodysplasia. She is doing well and is currently asymptomatic. During endoscopy, cranial displacement of the esophagogastric junction (Z line) was observed. Narrow-band imaging of the mucosa distal to the Z line did not show evidence of metaplastic change. Mucosal biopsy specimens obtained from this site showed gastric columnar cells and no goblet cells. Retrograde inspection of the gastric fundus did not show evidence of paraesophageal herniation. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is 171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 66 kg (145 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat an endoscopic biopsy in one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic surveillance every 12 months with biopsies is indicated in patients with Barrett esophagus and low-grade dysplasia after treatment of mucosal irregularities. This patient's endoscopy, however, shows no evidence of Barrett metaplasia or dysplasia. Therefore, endoscopic follow-up in one year is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

A laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication is indicated in patients with a type I hiatal hernia with persistent symptoms despite pharmacological treatment, symptomatic patients ineligible for pharmacological treatment, and patients with severe symptoms or complications of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD; e.g., bleeding, strictures, ulcerations) evident on endoscopy. This procedure is also often indicated in patients with type II, III, and IV hiatal hernias. However, this patient with a type I hiatal hernia is asymptomatic, and endoscopy shows no evidence of complications of GERD. A laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication is therefore not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

In asymptomatic patients with a sliding (type I) hiatal hernia, conservative management with reassurance and counseling on lifestyle modifications is indicated. Lifestyle modifications, including smoking cessation, alcohol cessation, and weight loss, should be discussed with all patients with hiatal hernia. If the patient develops symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), treatment with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is indicated. Surgical repair is only necessary if the patient has persistent symptoms despite pharmacological treatment, is not willing or able to take PPIs long-term, or has severe symptoms or complications of GERD (e.g., bleeding, strictures, ulcerations).
Image Description:

Type I (sliding): The gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) and the gastric cardia slide up into the mediastinum while the gastric fundus remains below the diaphragm.
Type II (paraesophageal): Part of the gastric fundus herniates into the thorax while the GEJ remains in its anatomical position below the diaphragm.
Type III (mixed): The GEJ and a portion of the gastric fundus prolapse through the hiatus.
Type IV (complex): herniation of any abdominal structure in addition to the stomach (e.g., colon, spleen)

D) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic hernia repair may be indicated in patients with paraesophageal hiatal hernias, especially in those with type IV hiatal hernias. Although this method has been largely replaced by the laparoscopic approach, it still plays role in select patients. However, this patient's endoscopy shows no evidence of paraesophageal herniation. This patient has an asymptomatic type I hiatal hernia, for which transthoracic hernia repair is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment with octreotide is typically used in variceal bleeding; however, it can also be used in patients with gastric angiodysplasia and recurrent bleeding as it diminishes the number of episodes of bleeding, the requirements for iron, and transfusion requirements. Although this patient had gastric angiodysplasia, she was treated endoscopically and has no findings suggestive of recurrent bleeding (e.g., symptoms of anemia due to chronic blood loss). Therefore, octreotide therapy is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Initiating treatment with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is indicated in patients with a type I hiatal hernia who have symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or complications of GERD, such as endoscopic evidence of intestinal metaplasia (Barrett esophagus). However, this patient is asymptomatic and has no evidence suggestive of Barrett esophagus; therefore, treatment with a PPI is not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient's endoscopic findings of a displaced Z line above the diaphragmatic hiatus with no evidence of paraesophageal herniation are consistent with a type I hiatal hernia.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism reports burning chest pain and intermittent dysphagia that have progressed during the past several weeks. Her current medications are hydrochlorothiazide, vitamin D, and levothyroxine.
A barium-swallow study shows a small degree of reflux with provocation and a small paraesophageal hernia. Her chest discomfort improves during 10 days of treatment with famotidine, but the dysphagia persists.
An electrocardiogram is normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carafate is less effective than treatment with acid suppressants and is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is not likely to change the patient’s management and is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Many patients with paraesophageal hernias develop symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux. These symptoms are best managed with acid suppressants, such as famotidine or lansoprazole. As the paraesophageal hernia enlarges, it can produce symptoms secondary to hernia torsion. Dysphagia, as is reported in this case, is a more alarming symptom and should prompt a diagnostic esophagogastroduodenoscopy in a patient who has not had this test previously.

Key learning point: Paraesophageal hernias frequently manifest with symptoms of esophageal reflux; the presence of dysphagia requires additional evaluation with a esophagogastroduodenoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Elective surgical hernia repair is reserved for failed medical management of symptoms, such as early satiety, postprandial pain, and vomiting attributable to the hernia.

E) INCORRECT:

Although proton pump inhibitors (e.g., lansoprazole) are more effective acid suppressants than H2 antagonists (e.g., famotidine), this patient reports decreased chest discomfort with famotidine. The persistent presence of dysphagia should prompt a diagnostic step first.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease after coronary artery bypass grafting, and gastroesophageal reflux disease presents with acute-onset epigastric and chest pain. The patient has associated nausea, with vomiting initially, but now she cannot vomit or retain any oral intake. Physical examination reveals no fever and no tenderness on chest percussion.
Electrocardiography reveals inferolateral T-wave inversions but no ST-segment changes.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
16,000
4500–11,000



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.2
12.0–16.0


Troponin T (ng/mL) (4th-generation assay)
<0.01
0–0.03


Lipase (U/liter)
41
0–160


The patient underwent a barium-swallow examination 2 weeks ago (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonic pseudo-obstruction is characterized by massive dilatation of the colon, generally in patients who are hospitalized with severe illness.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal adenocarcinoma is most likely to manifest with progressive weight loss and dysphagia; acute perforation is less likely. It does not typically manifest with symptoms of gastric-outlet obstruction.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s constellation of symptoms and imaging results suggests the presence of paraesophageal hernia with acute intrathoracic incarceration of the stomach. The patient’s prior barium-swallow examination reveals narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction and supradiaphragmatic positioning of the fundus and body of the stomach. The stomach can be seen in the chest area (parallel to the sternal wires) on this image.

Paraesophageal hernias represent 5% to 10% of intrathoracic hernias and are distinct from sliding hiatal hernias: Paraesophageal hernias develop when the fundus herniates through the diaphragm alongside the esophagus, whereas sliding hiatal hernias are characterized by cephalad movement of the gastroesophageal junction.

Paraesophageal hernias can result in potentially life-threatening complications, including intrathoracic incarceration of the stomach, reduced pulmonary reserve, bleeding, and perforation. Historically, paraesophageal hernias were thought to result in complications in 30% to 45% of patients, and prior recommendations were for surgical intervention in all patients. Currently, many centers offer laparoscopic repair for patients with symptomatic hernias, but expectant management may be suggested for asymptomatic patients.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with vomiting followed by acute chest and abdominal discomfort who is found to have a supradiaphragmatic position of the stomach fundus is paraesophageal herniation.

D) INCORRECT:

Sliding hiatal hernias are quite prevalent and are most often associated with an increased propensity for gastroesophageal reflux disease but would not explain an acute presentation that includes symptoms of gastric obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Boerhaave syndrome, a spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, can result from violent vomiting and is characterized by chest pain and fever, but patients do not typically have an inability to tolerate oral intake.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe epigastric pain and persistent retching for the past 4 hours. He reports feeling increasingly nauseated and has been unable to tolerate any oral intake. His medical history includes hypertension and occasional heartburn. On examination, he appears distressed with mild epigastric tenderness and tachycardia. Multiple attempts to place a nasogastric tube are unsuccessful. CT imaging shows a portion of the stomach herniated into the thoracic cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastric volvulus is a complication rather than cause of hiatal hernias, particularly type II paraesophageal hernias.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Type II paraesophageal hiatal hernia involves herniation of the gastric fundus into the thorax while the gastroesophageal junction remains in normal position. This patient's severe epigastric pain, persistent retching, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube comprise the Borchardt triad, indicating gastric outlet obstruction, which is a known complication of type II hernias requiring emergency surgical intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Type IV complex hiatal hernia involves herniation of abdominal structures in addition to the stomach. This condition is the rarest type of hiatal hernia, and imaging typically shows other herniated organs besides the stomach.

D) INCORRECT:

Type III mixed hiatal hernia involves both the gastroesophageal junction and gastric fundus herniating through the hiatus, but the acute presentation with classic Borchardt triad is characteristic of a different type of hiatal hernia.

E) INCORRECT:

Type I sliding hiatal hernia involves migration of the gastroesophageal junction and gastric cardia into the thorax. This condition typically manifests with gastroesophageal reflux symptoms rather than acute gastric outlet obstruction and inability to pass a nasogastric tube.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with 6 hours of severe epigastric pain and persistent dry heaving. She has a history of paraesophageal hernia and takes omeprazole daily. On examination, she appears uncomfortable with epigastric tenderness and mild tachycardia. Multiple attempts at nasogastric tube insertion are unsuccessful. CT imaging shows an upside-down stomach configuration. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serial abdominal examinations with supportive care
Emergency surgical consultation for operative intervention
Attempt endoscopic reduction and gastric decompression
Increase proton pump inhibitor dosage and initiate antiemetics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with serial examinations is appropriate for asymptomatic paraesophageal hernias but inadequate for acute gastric volvulus. The mechanical obstruction and risk of gastric ischemia require another urgent intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric decompression is not feasible given the inability to pass the nasogastric tube, which is part of the Borchardt triad. Fluoroscopic guidance would not overcome the mechanical gastric outlet obstruction caused by the volvulus.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation of severe epigastric pain, persistent retching, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube represents the classic Borchardt triad, which indicates gastric outlet obstruction from gastric volvulus. The upside-down stomach configuration on CT confirms this diagnosis. Strangulation and incarceration of the herniated stomach can result in ischemic complications that require emergency surgical intervention with hernia reduction and repair.

D) INCORRECT:

While endoscopic intervention may provide temporary decompression, it does not address the underlying mechanical problem of gastric volvulus secondary to a paraesophageal hernia. This patient's condition requires another intervention to prevent ongoing complications.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing proton pump inhibitor therapy addresses gastroesophageal reflux symptoms but does not resolve the mechanical obstruction and potential vascular compromise in gastric volvulus. Medical management alone is insufficient for this acute presentation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman undergoes an upper endoscopy as part of a workup for chronic iron deficiency anemia. The procedure reveals a 3-cm sliding hiatal hernia, with no evidence of esophagitis, mucosal breaks, or Barrett's esophagus. On questioning, she explicitly denies any symptoms of heartburn, regurgitation, dysphagia, or non-cardiac chest pain. Her medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's hiatal hernia?

choices.text: Initiation of a daily proton pump inhibitor
Counseling on weight loss and meal modifications
Barium esophagram to further characterize the hernia

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has an incidentally discovered, asymptomatic sliding (type I) hiatal hernia. This is the most common type of hiatal hernia and often requires no specific intervention if it does not cause symptoms or complications. Since the patient denies any symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and the endoscopy shows no evidence of esophagitis, Barrett's esophagus, or other mucosal injury, the most appropriate management is reassurance and observation. Treatment is indicated only for symptomatic patients. The hernia itself does not require treatment; rather, the associated conditions like GERD are the target of therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are the first-line medical therapy for symptomatic gastroesophageal reflux disease, which is commonly associated with hiatal hernias. However, this patient is explicitly asymptomatic, and the endoscopy shows no signs of acid-related mucosal damage. Therefore, initiating acid-suppressive therapy is not indicated, as there are no symptoms or pathology to treat.

C) INCORRECT:

Lifestyle modifications, including weight loss and dietary changes like avoiding trigger foods and late-night meals, are recommended for patients with symptomatic gastroesophageal reflux disease. While these are sound general health recommendations, they are not the primary management for an asymptomatic, incidentally discovered hiatal hernia.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical repair, such as a Nissen fundoplication, is considered for patients with severe or refractory gastroesophageal reflux disease symptoms despite optimal medical therapy or for complications of a hiatal hernia. Given that this patient is asymptomatic and has an uncomplicated sliding hernia, the risks associated with a major surgical procedure are not justified.

E) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow can provide detailed anatomical information about a hiatal hernia. However, an upper endoscopy has already confirmed the diagnosis of a sliding hernia and, more importantly, has ruled out mucosal complications like esophagitis or Barrett's esophagus. Further imaging is not necessary for an asymptomatic, uncomplicated hernia and would not change management.
questions.hint: Sliding hiatal hernias (type I) involve the protrusion of the gastroesophageal junction and the gastric cardia into the thorax.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman undergoes an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) for evaluation of iron deficiency anemia. She explicitly denies any heartburn, regurgitation, dysphagia, or chest pain. Her medical history is notable for osteoarthritis and hypertension. The EGD shows mild, diffuse gastritis and a finding described as 'the gastroesophageal junction is located 3 cm proximal to the diaphragmatic hiatus.' Biopsies of the gastritis are benign. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for the esophageal finding?

choices.text: Prescription for a histamine H2-receptor antagonist
Initiation of a daily proton pump inhibitor
Barium esophagram to assess hernia size

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication is a surgical procedure to repair a hiatal hernia and create an anti-reflux barrier. This procedure is reserved for patients with severe or refractory gastroesophageal reflux disease symptoms despite maximal medical therapy, or for complications related to large paraesophageal hernias. Because this patient has a small sliding hernia and is entirely asymptomatic, surgical intervention is not warranted.

B) CORRECT:

The endoscopic finding describes a sliding (Type I) hiatal hernia, in which the gastroesophageal junction and a portion of the stomach herniate into the mediastinum. These are extremely common, often incidental findings, particularly in older adults. Management is guided by symptoms, primarily those of gastroesophageal reflux disease. Since this patient is completely asymptomatic, conservative management with reassurance and counseling on lifestyle modifications is indicated. If the patient develops symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), treatment with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is indicated. Surgical repair is only necessary if the patient has persistent symptoms despite pharmacological treatment, is not willing or able to take PPIs long-term, or has severe symptoms or complications of GERD (e.g., bleeding, strictures, ulcerations).

C) INCORRECT:

Histamine H2-receptor antagonists are acid-suppressing medications used for mild or intermittent symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). While they can be effective for GERD, this patient is asymptomatic. There is no indication to start acid-suppressing therapy for an incidental hiatal hernia in the absence of reflux symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are first-line therapy for symptomatic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which is common in patients with hiatal hernias. However, this patient explicitly denies any symptoms of GERD, such as heartburn or regurgitation. Initiating a PPI is not indicated for an asymptomatic, incidentally discovered sliding hiatal hernia and would expose the patient to unnecessary medication side effects.

E) INCORRECT:

A barium esophagram is a useful imaging study to evaluate the anatomy and size of a hiatal hernia and to assess for esophageal motility disorders. However, the diagnosis of a sliding hiatal hernia has already been established by EGD. In an asymptomatic patient with an incidental finding, further anatomical characterization with a barium study would not alter the conservative management plan and is therefore unnecessary.
questions.hint: The endoscopic finding describes a sliding hiatal hernia. Management of this condition is primarily guided by the presence or absence of symptoms, such as those of gastroesophageal reflux disease.
